## Cultural Origins and General Symbolism

Camellias have a long history that goes back to East Asia, especially China and Japan, and this flower has been part of the Chinese and Japanese culture for thousands of years.(no content)The camellia plant was introduced into England from China around 1740, and was included in many of the French and English volumes about the 'language of flowers' published in the 19th century.

## Western vs Eastern Cultural Meanings

### Eastern Culture (China and Japan)
Camellia is the symbol of love in Eastern culture.(no content)In China, camellia has been cultivated for thousands of years and is a symbol of love and devotion, often used in Chinese art, literature, and poetry to represent beauty, purity, and faithfulness.(no content)Traditionally in China, the camellia was perceived as a union between two people - the calyx part of the flower represents a man, while the petals symbolize a woman.(no content)In Japan, the camellia is also a symbol of love and is associated with the samurai tradition. The flower is often worn as a hair ornament by Japanese women and is used in traditional tea ceremonies.

### Western Culture
In Western culture, the rose is the symbol of love. However, much of the literature about the meanings associated with flowers has been written from a European perspective, beginning in 19th century France and England, though often the blooms cited were native to eastern cultures, like the camellia, and had only been introduced into Europe in the 18th century.

## Color-Specific Symbolism

### White Camellia
In Chinese society, the white camellia flower meaning purity and the beauty of women. Such a flower is often used in traditional Chinese art and is especially popular at weddings because it represents the purity and beauty of the bride.(no content)The white camellia is often associated with purity and innocence. However, white camellias are associated with death, and they are a sign of misfortune in Japan, as giving white camellias is considered bad luck because it is associated with death and funerals.

### Red Camellia
The red camellia is often given as a gift to express love and passion.(no content)Red camellia symbolizes unconditional love, passion, and desire. People sometimes call red camellia "a flame in the heart".

## 19th Century Literature

Romantic sentiment was the hallmark of this era and underpins most of the emotions assigned to the camellia. The popularity of the camellia at that time was said to have been triggered by the courtesan Marguerite, heroine of Alexandre Dumas' novel, La Dame aux camelias, who loved camellia's.(no content)It was suggested that Dumas chose white camellia's because they signified the 'cool detachment' necessary for one in her trade.(no content)The white camellia flower holds a special significance in the iconic novel, To Kill A Mockingbird, by Harper Lee. When Mrs. Dubose passed away, she gave Jem a box with a white camellia inside. The camellia represents understanding and patience.(no content)In the Victorian era, camellias were a popular motif in literature and art, symbolizing life's beauty and brevity.

## Cultural Conflicts and Interpretations

There is much conflicting information in these books about the meanings associated with the camellia because they were written by different authors, each with their own interpretation that most likely mirrored what they had read about the bloom and the feelings it evoked for them.(no content)The meanings associated with the camellia vary across cultures as well as between individuals within a culture, and each is equally valid and deserves respect.
